> > This is very interesting experimental design.  Did
> > you also consider
> > inputting the start sequence with indices (e.g. M
> > inputs for data and N
> > inputs for "address" -- probably just setting one
> > address-line high, not
> > full binary numbers) and then ask for the data back
> > by repeating the
> > address sequence.
>
>No.  That would be a different problem, also worth
>doing.  I'm modeling phone dialing; you hear a phone
>number, 7 sounds in sequence, then after only a very
>short delay you repeat it back in the same sequence,
>either by speaking it or dialing it.

I'm not so sure about it being a different problem.  E.g. for short 
sequences at least, I can answer questions like "what digit was third" or 
"what came after the seven" as easily as I can repeat the sequence 
back.  And I would not assume that this is three separate mechanisms acting 
on the same data.

e.g. to go back to a point discussed a while back, breaking a problem into 
small pieces can make it harder.  So, for example, a net which can answer 
"what came after the seven" might make a necessary stepping-stone on the 
way to one which can recall the whole sequence.

Now an "indexed" approach is different, but I was thinking it was an easier 
experiment to set up than "what came after".  And it's pretty clear that if 
you could evolve indexed access, then it could be connected to a 
"sequencer" to form a solution to the original problem.

I'm not suggesting these are better experiments.  I'm just wondering 
out-loud about whether modularity could be evolved or enforced and whether 
it corresponds to anything in the way nature does it.

e.g. to get back to the lemur, it had to recall the sequence of some 
images.  I don't know about lemurs, but a humans memory in such a case 
comes in two parts:

1) recognize and remember what was in the pictures
2) remember the sequence

And (1) is _much_ easier if they are pictures of things you already 
know.  Thus our systems have to work, somehow, by forming temporary 
associations between positions in the sequence (possibly using a central 
concept of "sequence") and pre-existing concepts elsewhere in our brains...

I'm very interested in any ideas or experiments for how brains are able to 
apply different concepts together like this.  It's just the same as the 
discussion we had about whether 4play could exploit symmetry or not and 
whether a human brain can learn board-symmetry from checkers and apply it 
to chess.

> > >This is very similar to what is done by my 4Play
> > >program, except 4Play did more complex logic than
> > just
> > >repeating memorize values.
> >
> > I'd say this was asking for a more complex net,
> > however...
>
>Which do you think is more complex?

The phone numbers are more complex.  Assuming I remember 4play correctly, 
it only had to recall the positions of 4 symbols amongst 4 
places.  Treating that naively, it's only 8 bits of data.  A seven-digit 
phone number is 28 bits of data, even without questions of remembering the 
"cursor" position...

         Ian Badcoe
